title: Mitochondrial Dysfunction and Disease
content: Dr. Vamsi Mootha is focused on finding clinical treatments for the 300-some identified rare mitochondrial disorders, which have potential implications for longevity and chronic disease. He elucidates how the latest research could give insight into conditions related to aging, including but not limited to Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes, cancer, and much more.

title: Potential Therapies for Mitochondrial Diseases
content: Dr. Vamsi Mootha discusses some of the most exciting potential therapies for mitochondrial diseases such as hypoxia (oxygen deprivation), how exercise affects the mitochondria, the use of hyperbaric chambers for cancer therapy, and the mechanisms by which metformin might confer longevity benefits in a non-diabetic individual.

title: Mitochondrial Mutations and Diseases
content: How many diseases can be attributed to mitochondrial mutations? [28:45]; Mitochondrial diseases Vamsi studies in his lab [55:15]; Mitochondria and oxygen: Poor oxygen utilization and excess oxygen contributes to the pathology seen in some of the rare mitogenic diseases [1:02:00]; Chronic diseases have altered mitochondria: Evidence for mitochondrial dysfunction causing Parkinson’s Disease [2:04:30]; Why Vamsi is very optimistic about the possibility of targeting mitochondrial proteins as therapies [2:09:30];

title: Mitochondria and Disease
content: Dr. Vamsi Mootha discusses the role of mitochondria in various diseases such as aging, type 2 diabetes, cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and Parkinson’s disease.

title: Mitochondrial Diseases and Chronic Diseases
content: Dr. Vamsi Mootha shares his knowledge on mitochondrial diseases and their potential implications in the context of chronic diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes, cancer, and much more. He also discusses how mitochondrial dysfunction can cause Parkinson’s disease and how targeting mitochondrial proteins can be a potential therapy for chronic diseases.

title: The Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard
content: Creation and vision for the Broad Institute was “an experiment” by Eric Lander – one of the leaders of the human genome sequencing project. Lander wanted to create an institute that could utilize genomics for the improvement of biomedicine. It is joint between Harvard and MIT and includes all the hospitals in Boston. It is a forum where researchers can collaborate and pursue research that they would not be able to do in their individual laboratories. Either researchers are employed by the institute or employed elsewhere (as is the case for Vamsi) as their primary appointment, but spend time at the institute working on collaborative projects.

title: Vamsi’s academic background
content: Growing up, he was convinced that he wanted to be a doctor. When he was in high school, he fell in love with math and went to Stanford as a math and computer science major. As a college student, his advisor introduced him to the work of Sam Karlin – a statistician who developed some of the underlying methods for biomolecular sequence analysis. Vamsi worked on a DNA sequence analysis as a college student: writing code to analyze DNA and protein sequences. He fell in love with the research and his advisor suggested that he consider a career in medicine. He applied simultaneously to PhD programs in mathematical biology and also applied to a joint program between Harvard and MIT (HST): an interdisciplinary program that brings together engineering, physical, and biological sciences. Completed his residency in internal medicine at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston.

title: Advice for college students and med students considering a career in medicine and/or medical research
content: No relevant content found.

title: Medical School and Research
content: Going to medical school is one of the best ways to understand human physiology. In college and undecided about medical school, lean towards a PhD. At the post-medical school juncture and want to pursue research: Is there a benefit to doing a residency? At least do an internship in order to have a license and can prescribe medicine.

title: Vamsi's Focus on Mitochondria and Mitochondrial Disorders
content: Vamsi no longer sees patient and now focuses on research full time. He leads a research group that focuses on mitochondria and mitochondrial disorders. The long term goal is for his research to impact patients: rather than care for them directly he works to develop new diagnostics and drugs, which will be used in front-line patient treatment. He was drawn to the organelle as a first-year medical student.

title: The Mitochondrial Genome
content: The original gram-negative rod (bacterium) had about 1,000-2,000 genes and the (archaea) species it merged with had around 2,000 genes. The two merging species had a comparable number of genes and yet today, humans have 20,000 to 30,000 genes inside of the nucleus, with 13 genes inside the mitochondria.

title: Endosymbiosis of the Mitochondrion
content: The current theory of origin is a process known as  endosymbiosis: a bacteria organism resembling a modern gram-negative rods (a bacteria shaped like a rod that is gram-negatively stained for identification) that merged with a modern-day archaea species. The hypothesis is that the bacteria merged with modern-day archaea, giving rise to eukaryotes with a nuclei (three domains of life: Archaea, Bacteria, Eukaryote), around 1.5 billion years ago. Endosymbiosis (the merging of bacteria and archaea) of the mitochondrion only took place once.

title: Mitochondrial Mutations and Diseases
content: There are about 250 different syndromes (particular mutation associated with a clinical phenotype) of the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). That number of mutation only refers to mitochondrial DNA disorders. There is not a solid understanding of whether mtDNA mutations have a higher or lower frequency on a probability basis (with 16,000 base pairs) compared to the nuclear genome. There is ascertainment bias in clinical medicine regarding mitochondrial disease. Mitochondrial disease is largely attributed to maternal inheritance. The nuclear genome was sequenced in 2001 but the mitochondrial DNA was sequenced 20 years earlier in 1981. From 1988 when the first two papers (1, 2) were published, reporting first mtDNA mutations with the disease phenotype, it has been relatively easy to sequence it and its associated mutations. Comparatively, the research community has identified about 300 genes in the nuclear genome that underlie mtDNA disorders (since 2001).

title: Biogenesis: mtDNA and nuclear DNA communication in the mitochondrion
content: About 1,100 proteins that are made by the nuclear genome find their way into the mitochondrion. Those 1,100 proteins have to work with the 13 mtDNA proteins within the organelle. Some mechanisms are known and many are not. For example, in response to exercise there is a transcriptional program response. Within the organelle, replication factors turn on in the organelle that essentially says: “make more of the nuclear DNA components, mitochondrial DNA components and mitochondrial DNA-encoded proteins”. The transcription program increases mitochondrial density in a given cell. Within a myocyte (muscle cell), physiologic-level signalling instruct a cell to make more DNA in response to exercise. One important signal that induces mitochondrial biogenesis is AMP kinase: change in the ATP:ADP ratio. There is sensing of ATP:ADP ratio decrease that promotes an increase in AMPK activity. It is still an open question as to how exactly the number of mitochondria is sensed and regulated but some of the inputs have been identified. Transcriptional cofactor PGA-1α regulates mitochondria biogenesis. SIRT1, which utilizes NAD as a cofactor directly affects PGC-1α activity through deacetylation.

title: Mitochondrial DNA in Cells
content: The cell type with the highest number of copies of the mitochondrial genome is the unfertilized egg – it has half a million copies of mitochondrial DNA. Sperm has up to a few hundred mtDNA. Red blood cells have no mtDNA. In most non-dividing tissues (e.g muscles and neurons), the half-life of mitochondria is on the order of a few days. A dividing cell needs to double the number of mitochondria then partition the replication and repeat.

title: Paternal mtDNA Transmission
content: The textbook teaching is that mtDNA is transmitted exclusively via maternal lineage. However, in a rare exception, one case report of a biopsy reported mtDNA molecules of an individual with two differential haplotypes and concluded paternal mtDNA transmission. Another paper claimed a few families in which mtDNA paternal transmission occurred. While paternal mtDNA transmission is a rare event, it is an active area of research. If the results are not a technical artifact, there is an opportunity to learn about the mechanisms of maternal transmission.

title: Mitochondria 101
content: The mitochondria is the key place where energy transformations take place. A cell takes in glucose, free fatty acid, substrate for energy and in 10 steps glucose gets turned into pyruvate. Once glucose gets turned into pyruvate, there are two scenarios dependent on oxygen availability and ATP demand: if oxygen is scarce relative to ATP demand, the “inefficient” route is that pyruvate gets turned into lactate. With low ATP demand and sufficient oxygen, pyruvate converts into Acetyl-CoA, a substrate for the electron transport chain. The electron transport chain in the mitochondria: The NADH/NAD ratio is essential for mitochondrial function.

title: Mitochondria and Energy from Food
content: One type of energy in the mitochondria is the electromotive force. Energy from food: the mitochondria takes fats, carbohydrates and proteins and breaks down the energy forms, harnessing the electrons. The NADH/NAD ratio is an electron carrier that can power certain types of enzymes. Alternatively, the NADH/NAD ratio can also be converted to a gradient, or voltage, across the inner mitochondrial membrane that can drive transport. Chemical bonds from food are broken and energy is released, creating an electron gradient. The gradient powers the phosphorylation of ADP (putting a phosphate group onto the ADP), creating ATP. Voltage is an energy potential gradient created by disproportionate placement of electrons (across the membrane). The ability to keep a difference in charge across the membrane powers the “work”.

title: NAD and NADH in Mitochondria
content: The classical teaching is that NAD is the oxidized form (without two electrons) electron carrier. When NAD has two electrons it will be in NADH form – holding energy that can catalyze reactions. Electrons are transferred from NADH to the electron transport chain that “conducts” the electron until they hit oxygen and make water. During that process, protons are pumped across the inner mitochondrial membrane generating about 150 MV that can be used to do work – including catalyzing conversion of ADP to ATP (oxidative phosphorylation). In addition to the role of NAD as an electron carrier, the NAD molecule can also be used as a substrate for other reactions. NAD as a cofactor is used by sirtuins and PARPs in the DNA damage response pathways. If there is a cell with damaged DNA, the NAD can decline rapidly. NAD is an electron carrier, the cell’s ability to carry charge degrades.

title: Aging at a Mitochondrial Level
content: NAD levels decline with age and elicits some key questions: Is that due to greater demand for it? Is that due to reduction in (NAD) production? And the clinical question is if there is any benefit to replacing it? Comparing a muscle biopsy of individuals of various ages, there will be a gradual decline as a function of age in: NAD content, quantity of mitochondria, the VO2 max of skeletal muscle.

title: Mitochondrial Diseases
content: His lab studies rare inborn errors of mitochondrial metabolism; typically single gene disorders of a mitochondrion that is defective at birth due to recessive mutations in the nuclear genome or mutations in the mitochondrial genome. There are about 300 mitogenic disorders of the mitochondria and he studies the consequences of these mutations. The phenotypic spectrum of these mutations follow a bimodal distribution: recessive mutations in the nuclear genome – where Vamsi’s lab spends more time – present early in infancy and are more severe mutations in the mitochondrial genome present a bit later life. Mitochondrial disorders impact almost any organ system and Leigh syndrome represents one type of clinical manifestation of a mitochondrial disease. Another set of disorders impact the skeletal muscle.

title: Leigh Syndrome
content: There are about 80 different genes that can be mutated to give rise to the syndrome. A subacute degeneration of gray matter – rapid neurodegeneration. Most children are born developmentally okay and within the first couple of months of life contract a stressor that will put them into a neurometabolic crisis. MRI scans reveal lesions in the brainstem, brainstem, spinal cord, which corresponding to legions of necrosis. The community of researchers studying the disease are looking to identify what it is about the broken mitochondria that gives rise to the aforementioned phenotype. Genes in the nuclear genome have been mapped – some of which are in the mtDNA – but there is not yet a clear answer. One possible similarity that Peter puts forth: other forms of neurodegeneration, such as Alzheimer’s disease, have been recently argued to be neuronal energy crises.

title: Mitochondria and Oxygen
content: When mitochondria and oxygen are discussed, ROS signaling commonly comes to mind. Mitochondria are an important source of ROS – an essential signaling molecule. The “dogma” is that when the “powerhouse” of the cell is “broken,” the pathogenesis equates to not enough ATP produced inside of the cell. But, in addition to producing ATP, the mitochondria also consume oxygen. In fact, most of the oxygen in a cell is consumed by the mitochondria. When a patient has a birth defect of the mitochondria, in addition to not being able to produce sufficient ATP, they also have excess oxygen. Oxygen delivery to the cell is typically not a problem but the oxygen utilization is poor. It may not be just about ATP production… it’s also about excess, unused oxygen. One of the consequences of mitochondrial dysfunction is excess, unused oxygen. If a mitochondrion is failing to do its job, oxygen utilization will be failing.

title: Dioxygen toxicity
content: Enzymes are programed to operate within an oxygen range inside of the cell. When the mitochondrion is not functioning properly and oxidation levels rise, and the excess dioxygen can oxidize and damage enzymes

title: Mitochondrial Disorder Diagnosis
content: To diagnose patients, Ron Haller has proposed measuring oxygen extraction to look for patients with high venous oxygen

title: VO2 Max and Mitochondrial Function
content: On a treadmill, in order to stress the system, two things would be measured: the amount of oxygen going in and the concentration of oxygen coming out. The difference is the extraction (of oxygen). Ron Haller will use such a physiological study to look at cardiac output as well as the oxygen tensions on the arterial and venous sides. Assessment of an oxygen mass balance can quantify the number of O2 molecules – being delivered, extracted as well as returned to the venous system. For patients with inherited mitochondrial disease, cardiac output is high and oxygen extraction is low. Iñigo San Millán is looking at type 2 diabetes as an early indicator of mitochondrial myopathy.

title: Mitochondrial Myopathy Hypothesis for Type 2 Diabetes
content: In early states of insulin resistance, the muscle becomes inefficient at oxidative phosphorylation (marked by high levels of resting lactate). Skeletal muscles from individuals with prediabetes, as well as biopsies of healthy individuals with a family history of diabetes, have a reduced number of mitochondria. 1000 genes required for mitochondria are suppressed as an entire pathway (not any one gene). Vo2 max for these individuals is also low. It is still not clear if mitochondrial dysfunction is causal for diabetes or if it is an early, secondary symptom that precedes mitochondria gene expression.

title: Mendelian Randomization
content: Population variation associated with a particular marker can be turned into a bell curve, based on population genetics. This method requires caution when asserting correlation. Genes under investigation could control something else related to the disease that could have a counterbalancing effect. Methods like mendelian randomization are becoming viable to answer cause-effect pathways of mitochondrial function but requires heavily genotyped individuals biomarkers for mitochondrial function.

title: Mitochondrial Disease and Aging
content: Rare genetic disorders reveal pathology pathogenesis of the organelle that can potentially be applied to common aging phenomena. Implications of understanding mitochondrial disease pathway are significant both for chronic and risk reduction of chronic disease. The big question in the field of rare mitogenetic disorders: which forms of the pathogenesis bears any relevance to the common aging process? The 300 different forms of monogenic mitochondrial disease are terrible diseases for which therapies are needed. There is also a hope that some of them may bear some relevance to the common form of aging.

title: Muscle cell inflammation and mtDNA damage
content: Could muscle cell inflammation (a signature of aging) be caused by mtDNA damage being confused as foreign bacteria? Another study finding supported inflammation in response to mtDNA and formulated peptides. To test the hypothesis, STING pathway was utilized – blocking the ability of a cell to sense general nucleic acid (independent of nuclear or mitochondrial origins). In the two examples – either by mitochondrial damage or acute injury – there is an inflammatory response due to the exposure of mtDNA, interpreted by the immune system as bacterial.

title: Exercise and mitochondrial health
content: Exercise is one of the best ways to turn over bad mitochondria and induce mitochondrial biogenesis. Is there an optimal exercise strategy for mitochondrial health? Three types of (loose) exercise buckets being strength training, aerobic training requiring maximum mitochondrial output with minimal generation of lactate, and anaerobic training that demands ATP and favors the lactate production pathway. Although the proven relationship is not yet clear, there are predicted non-linear dynamics of mitochondria as a function of both age and exercise. The PGC-1 alpha program turns on mitochondrial biogenesis while simultaneously turns on autophagy programs – turning over bad mitochondria while creating more healthy mitochondria.

title: Autophagy and mitochondrial turnover
content: With proper exercise regimes, there have been observed transcriptional programs with multiple inputs that will turn on all 1,000 proteins to produce more mitochondria and induce old mitochondrial turnover. The PGC-1 alpha program turns on mitochondrial biogenesis while simultaneously turns on autophagy programs – turning over bad mitochondria while creating more healthy mitochondria.

title: The Role of ROS in Mitobiogenesis and Cancer
content: Antioxidants in conjunction with exercise erases some of the beneficial effects of exercise. ROS play an important role in mitobiogenesis signaling and also turning over old mitochondria that are not beneficial. ROS plays an important role in selectively targeting a cancer cell, so blocking ROS with antioxidants in a cancer patient would be detrimental.

title: Metformin's Impact on Exercise and Lactate Levels
content: Individuals with diabetes and also those who are insulin resistant are benefited by metformin. Peter self-experiments to observe the effects of metformin on exercise. His lactate performance curve (LPC) comparison reveals higher lactate levels when on metformin. Metformin inhibits complex one, the body may preferentially opt against shuttling pyruvate into the mitochondria, disproportionately keeping pyruvate outside of the organelle and turning it into lactate. Vamsi published a study of healthy individuals and patients with mitochondrial disease who did an exercise test on a treadmill. The study compared resting, peak, and recovery metabolomic response to the exercise. The study could be replicated to compare impaired complex one deficiency patient group as a result of taking Metformin, rather than having complex one inhibition due to mitochondrial dysfunction.

title: How Might Metformin Confer Longevity Benefits?
content: Blocking the Complex may turn on 15 of the 17 inputs needed to induce mitobiogenesis and other parts of the cell as well. One of the gene sets most associated with a longevity phenotype was the mitochondrial electron transport chain. However, one of the gene sets associated with a reduced lifespan was the mitochondria electron transport chain. The subsets were distinct – 90 genes total are required for the electron transport chain and oxidative phosphorylation. One hypothesis has to do with the strength of the allele: gently blocking the ETC (as metformin may do) rather than significantly inhibiting the ETC encoding. Metformin may block the ETC such that it elicits a homeostatic response that is net adaptive. There are rare cases with drugs related to metformin, like Phenoformin, that can result in fatal lactic acidosis. An experiment evaluating the cross product of exercise and metformin – like that similar to the Ron Kahn study – would help inform whether the addition of metformin offers incremental benefit or counteracts the benefit of optimized exercise, sleep, and nutrition.

title: Hypoxia as a Potential Therapeutic Option for Mitochondrial Disease
content: There have been observations where too much oxygen can be damaging. ATP levels are defended by glycolysis (i.e., not a disorder of energy deficiency). There are high levels of unused oxygen observed (despite high energy output a high level of oxygen returns to the lungs). Vamsi’s lab now investigates ways to limit or reduce the delivery of oxygen. Using hypoxia chambers in mouse model studies in which air is diluted with nitrogen (21% oxygen reduced to 11%). In some of the models with mitochondrial disease there has been a measured benefit.

title: Leigh Syndrome Mouse Model
content: A mouse model with Leigh syndrome (a recessive loss of one of the nuclear subunits of Complex I) has an archetype disease process observed. Mouse is born looking healthy. Within 30-35 days begins to display symptoms. By day 55, among other symptoms, it has lesions on the brain MRI and the initial cause of death is probably brain driven, although other tissues are also affected. If the mice were grown at 11% rather than 21%, they survive to a median of one year (half of their normal, 2-year lifespan) and looked well.

title: Hyperbaric Oxygen and Cancer Treatment
content: Previously, hyperbaric oxygen has been proposed as a treatment for mitochondrial rejuvenation. Vamsi’s lab experimented with hyperoxia conditions as well. 55% oxygen conditions, as is the saturation in an operating room. The mice with Leigh Syndrome die within a few days of exposure. There have been some anecdotes that suggest high oxygen levels on a broken electron transport chain can be very damaging, in line with the experimental findings in mice. There is a subset of tumors – where there may be mitochondrial mutations to begin with – for which Vamsi’s lab is exploring hyperoxic exposure. Hyperbaric oxygen has been proposed as a cancer therapy in the past. There have been mixed signals of efficacy. It may be that with precise targeting, (based on mitochondria markers) hyperbaric oxygen can be effectively used for certain cancer treatments.

title: Mitochondrial Dysfunction and Parkinson's Disease
content: Chronic diseases have altered mitochondria: Evidence for mitochondrial dysfunction causing Parkinson’s Disease. Not clear if dysfunctional mitochondria is the cause or part of the disease effect. Systems biology and insights taken from rare disease research may inform a subset of chronic disease understanding. The causal hypothesis for Parkinson’s Disease is particularly compelling. The pathology of rare monogenic mitochondrial disease resembles molecular features of mitochondrial dysfunction seen in Parkinson’s Disease. In some Parkinson’s Disease cases, the root cause is mitochondrial toxicity that results in dopamine loss (via herbicide or insecticide exposure, which are toxic to Complex I). Evidence for direct toxicity to mitochondria in humans can give rise to Parkinson-like disease phenotype. Mouse models given a high does of rotenone – a Complex I poison – has been used as a model for Parkinson’s Disease.

title: Targeting Mitochondrial Proteins as Therapies
content: Why Vamsi is very optimistic about the possibility of targeting mitochondrial proteins as therapies. In the laboratory, mitochondrial disease can be alleviated in a preclinical way using hypoxia. Another preclinical approach uses protein prosthesis. Proteins from other organisms are transplanted into human cells (ex-vivo) with mitochondrial disease and effectively rescue the cells. As a result of reductive evolution, certain organisms lost parts of their ETC and others, their entire ETC. One way organisms who have lost their entire ETC may be able to survive is because they gained a new protein in replacement. These isolated proteins placed in a human cell can poison the mitochondria in five different ways but the cell will reproduce. Hypothesis that prosthesis corrects part of the redox imbalance but not the full proton pump capability of the ETC.

title: Protein Prosthesis and Mitochondrial Function in Disease
content: Has potential to be used to either bypass or augment some broken functions of the mitochondria in disease like fatty liver and diabetes. In addition to bypassing a mitochondrial malfunction, protein prosthesis could feasibly enhance mitochondrial function.

title: Multi-Pronged Approaches to Treating Disease
content: Drugs like statins, metformin, rapamycin all act on multiple “switches” at the same time that are net beneficial. It is no coincidence that most effective, potent clinical agents, that involve such “multi-pronged” inputs within a system, come from naturally occurring substances. Natural products are chemistries that have evolved over hundreds of millions of years to target physiological systems.

title: The Potential Benefits of Breathing Thin Air for Chronic Disease
content: Vamsi’s fantasy experiment in an unconstrained world [2:20:15]. One possible experiment would be motivated by his lab’s recent work on oxygen and mitochondrial dysfunction. In preclinical models, oxygen depleted air seems to be beneficial. In normal aging, when there is a subtle decline in mitochondrial activity, is there excess oxygen and would breathing thinner air be beneficial? Crossover study with two treatment groups at different elevation, large participant cohort, treatment length in the order of months to years. Compare biomarkers of aging and age associated disorders. To test the idea that thin air might be beneficial for chronic disease. This type of natural experiment has actually been reported in one paper from the early 1970s, published by the Indian army. The study reported on health outcomes of more than 100,000 troops deployed to the Indo-China border. One group was at extremely high altitude and another group was not for a number of years. Although other parameters – such as food, temperature, activity – were not controlled for, the altitudes and therefore oxygen saturation between the two locations were different. Chronic diseases were reduced during the time living at altitude.
